Title: Combating gender stereotypes: SC announces release of a handbook for judges and lawyers
Content:
Chief Justice of India (CJI) D.Y. Chandrachud on Aug 16 announced the release of a handbook to assist judges and lawyers in identifying, understanding and combating gender stereotypes about women in legal proceedings.

The handbook, made available for both judges and lawyers, contains a glossary of gender unjust terms and suggests alternative words or phrases which may be used in pleadings, orders and judgments.

It explains stereotypes and helps judges to avoid them by identifying language that promotes gender stereotypes and offering them with alternative words and phrases. 


тАЬThe handbook identifies common stereotypes about women, many of which have been utilised by courts in the past and demonstrates how they are inaccurate and how they distort the application of law,тАЭ CJI Chandrachud said in open court addressing the lawyers. 

He said the release of the handbook is not to cast doubt or criticise past judgments, but to indicate how stereotypes may unwittingly be employed.

The objective of the handbook is to raise awareness against utilisation of harmful stereotypes, particularly those prejudicial to women, the CJI added. 

The handbook also contains previous judgments of the Supreme Court rejecting gender based stereotypes.

(Source: IANS)

Title: Specialised courses for Indian students in the USA to commence from 2024
Content:
The US state department has designed specialised courses for Indian students, in line with India's New National Education Policy (NEP), that will offer a pathway to a Master's in the USA for Indian students.

Over 20 USA universities and 15 Indian universities are in talks with the US state department on how to take advantage of these newly introduced courses.

Comes with a three-year stay back

To explore employment opportunities and pay their student loans, the programs, which are of one-year duration, will offer Indian students a three-year stay back in the USA.

The industry specialisation

Since they are one-year Master's programmes, they would aim to provide industry-specific training. Moreover, the disciplines of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) would be offered.

The specialised courses are likely to commence in the fall semester of 2024 (late August to early September).

The inception

According to reports, the program has been designed by Akhilesh Lakhtakia, who studied India's New National Education Policy (NEP) 2020 for a year. Lakhtakia is also a Jefferson Science Fellow at the South and Central Asia Bureau of the US state department.

His mandate was to come up with a programme that would benefit US and Indian governments, US universities, and Indian students.

Reportedly, Lakhtakia described the programme as тАШstudent-centred, flexible, multidisciplinary, futuristic, and internationalтАЩ. He stated that the state department had brought him to create a win-win for both countries, in line with IndiaтАЩs NEP, but in his mind, the client was always Indian students.
